Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the Thermal History of Crustal Magma Storage Through Crystal Records and Numerical Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
The processes involved in formation and storage of magma within the Earth?s upper crust are of fundamental importance to understanding volcanoes and volcanic hazards. Previous NSF-supported research by two of the PIs showed that at Mount Hood, Oregon, only a small fraction (most likely less than 1%) of the total time that magma is stored underground is spent at high enough temperatures that would allow magma to be easily mobilized and erupted. Partial data sets for other volcanoes suggest that these conditions are widespread, but this remains to be tested. This new project will address the questions of whether magmas in general are subject to similar storage conditions as those seen at Mount Hood, and what are the fundamental controls on the processes of magma storage underneath volcanoes. The project will address these questions using geochemical measurements of crystals that grew beneath the surface and will provide information on the duration and temperature of magma storage. These results will be combined with advanced computer models of magma chambers to explore the interplay of magma addition, heat loss and changes in magma composition. In addition to contributions to the science of volcanology and geochemistry, the work will have impacts in understanding volcanic hazards ? in particular, the percentage of time that different magma bodies spend in an eruptible state (and, critically, the processes that control that percentage of time) will provide insight into the hazard represented by different volcanoes and will also provide a better context to interpret the results of seismic imaging or other remote-sensing applications. This project will contribute to training the next-generation STEM workforce by providing support for a postdoctoral researcher and three graduate students, one at each institution. At OSU and at UCD undergraduates will also take part in the research.

This project will integrate observational data with numerical modeling for selected volcanic systems, to address the broader question: ?What are the thermal and physical conditions of magma storage in the Earth?s crust, and what are the primary controls on those conditions?? This project will build on our results for Mount Hood and on existing partial data sets by exploring two high-priority specific questions that pertain to the maturation of magmatic systems: 1) What is the role of volume of the shallow reservoir? How do magma storage conditions vary over erupted volumes of <1 to >10 km3? and 2) What is the role of composition? Is there a difference between the thermal history of magma storage in dacitic and rhyolitic systems? The results of this project will provide some of the first observational data on the thermal histories of magma storage, and the numerical modeling will allow us to put these results into a generalizable thermodynamic framework. These results will provide a critical, observation-based understanding of the physical conditions of magma storage, which in turn will provide a better understanding of magma reservoir processes. Ultimately we will build a framework in which to understand various aspects of crystal records such as the interpretation of mineral thermobarometry, textural information, and time scales captured by mineral zonation. The results of this project will have broad implications within the field of igneous petrology/geochemistry by providing a conceptual framework for the processes that operate within magma reservoirs ? and crucially, the time scales relevant to the different processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative research: Quantifying the thermal history of crustal magma storage through crystal records and numerical modeling

The processes involved in formation and storage of magma within the Earth?s upper crust are of fundamental importance to understanding how volcanoes work and therefore for quantifying volcanic hazards. This project addressed two questions: 1. Are magmas stored beneath most volcanoes at conditions that are relatively immobile, as was found for a previous study at Mount Hood? And 2. What controls the processes and conditions of magma storage underneath volcanoes? The project addressed these questions using geochemical measurements of crystals that grew beneath the surface that provided information on the duration and temperature of magma storage. Previous NSF-supported research by two of the PIs showed that at Mount Hood, Oregon, only a small fraction (likely less than 1%) of the total time that magma is stored underground is spent at high enough temperatures that would allow magma to be easily mobilized and erupted. We found that for most of the smaller volcanoes studied (Lassen Volcanic Center, CA, Mount Hood, OR, Mount St Helens, WA, and Volcan Quizapu, Chile, and Huyanaputina, Chile), the volcanic crystals recorded storage mostly at low-temperature, relatively immobile conditions. This is important because it suggests that volcanoes are not constantly ?primed? for eruption, but instead it requires some run-up time in order to mobilize and erupt the magma. One possible exception was Mount Pinatubo, Philippines, where the crystals could have been stored in hotter (i.e. eruptible) conditions for most of their history. A second major finding from this study is that there is no clear relationship between the percentage of time that magma beneath volcanoes spends in a mobile state and the size of the eruption produced. This means that within this category of relatively small eruptions (<10 km3 of magma erupted), larger eruptions don?t need to be preceded by longer periods of unrest than smaller eruptions. Among the larger eruptions studied (>100 km3), there were some that recorded longer periods of time at high temperatures, suggesting that there may be some types of eruptions that do require a longer ?priming? time. These results were combined with advanced computer models of magma chambers to explore the interplay of magma addition, heat loss and changes in magma composition in determining when an eruption will happen. These model results suggest that there is a key relationship between the rate that magma is fed into the reservoir from below and the size of the magma reservoir that seems to be the main control on whether an eruption will happen (and how frequently eruptions occur). In addition, volcanic gases play a key role in whether eruptions happen, and if they do, whether they will be explosive or produce lava flows.

In addition to contributions to the science of volcanology and geochemistry, this work will have impacts in understanding volcanic hazards ? in particular, our better understanding of the percentage of time that different magma bodies spend in an eruptible state (and, critically, the processes that control that percentage of time) will provide insight into the hazard represented by different volcanoes and will also provide a better context to interpret the results of seismic imaging or other remote-sensing applications. This project has also contributed to training the next-generation STEM workforce by providing support for a postdoctoral researcher and three graduate students. At OSU and at UCD undergraduates also took part in the research, learning valuable skills and getting experience in how research is done.
